author: Kavita Upadhyay
text:
The ninth edition of the Zee Jaipur Literature Festival (JLF) began on Thursday with much fanfare as novelist, poet and literary critic Margaret Atwood spoke about the “power” and “optimism” of words and literature.

Ms. Atwood, who delivered the keynote address at JLF, said, “Writing is a very optimistic art. It is a way in which the unknown, the obscure, the undervalued and the neglected can become known. Not much money is needed to write, only time and determination.”

She said there were “many darknesses” in the world that portray themselves through poverty, discrimination and oppressive regimes, but there are as many voices to dissent the “darknesses.” “There are many darknesses, but there are also many voices,” Ms. Atwood said, calling it an “optimistic thing.”

“Some people believe that reading is diminishing. I dispute that thought,” said Ms. Atwood.

According to her, reading was increasing and it was only the platforms to read that were changing.

“In places with no library, no accessibility to books, or no school there’s probably a cell phone. People can use cell phones, and read and write stories,” she said.
title: Writing is an optimistic art: Margaret Atwood
